author: @vighnesh153
text: Here's the modified code for the Qt5 version:   from PyQt5 import QtGui, QtCore, QtWidgets     class Window(QtWidgets.QWidget):       def __init__(self, _title, _w, _h):         super(Window, self).__init__()         self.init(_title, _w, _h)         self.btn = None       def init(self, _title, _w, _h):         self.setGeometry(100, 100, _w, _h)         self.setWindowTitle(_title)         self.setWindowIcon(QtGui.QIcon('racecar.png'))         self.home()       def home(self):         self.btn = QtWidgets.QPushButton("Quit", self)         self.btn.setGeometry(0, 0, 50, 50)         self.btn.move(100, 100)         self.btn.clicked.connect(Window.close_)           self.btn.show()       @staticmethod     def close_():         print("closing")         exit(2)     def main():     app = QtWidgets.QApplication([])     window = Window('Testing', 800, 600)     window.show()     app.exec_()     if __name__ == '__main__':     main()

author: @christopherbowler6076
text: Im using Atom Editor with Python on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS and my button wasn't showing even though there were no errors on my code. I found on Stackoveflow a similar issue posted. The correction is as follows: Original Code: btn = QtGui.QPushButton("Quit")  Change to this: btn = QtGui.QPushButton("Quit", self)  Now the button is visible and clickable.  Thanks for the great tutorials

author: @Theanimatorr56
text: Just thought I'd share. I spent the last ~20 minutes racking my brain trying to figure out why my button wouldn't show up. I tried all the examples people posted in the comments, but nothing would work. Only after completely retyping everything into a new file and checking line by line did I realize that my indentation of "def home(self):" was one space off. Check your indentation, folks!
